eventName: Amit is walking up Mount Snowdon to raise money for Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my just giving page.

I have always wanted to climb up Mount Snowdon and this weekend I have the opportunity to fulfill one of my dreams with close friends and would like to raise as much money as possible for a charity that is very dear to mine and my friend's heart ❤ 💙  

The challenge is that we will need to carry 130kg between us so 13kg each.

My wife , Nisha ,was diagnosed with an incurable blood cancer 3 years ago and despite all the chemotherapy, stem cell transplant and adverse side effects that she has done and suffered,  she is still fighting , despite it coming back. We as a family couldn't have done this without the support of family, friends and Macmillan and will need them again as we begin to fight the next journey together. 

My brother too was diagnosed with testicular cancer recently and my friend's dad with prostate and bone cancer so this is for all the strong people in my life who have been and are going through this tough journey as well as their carers, families and loved ones. 

Please click on the link and donate whatever you can to help Macmillan to continue to provide support to anyone affected by cancer ♋

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story: I’m hoping to raise some money for this charity by taking on the challenge of ‘Walk/Running to the North Pole’ 🎅🏻🎄 Virtually I’ll add 😄 Basically to complete 100km in 6 weeks. I’m not out to raise a mountain of money (although that would be amazing🤩) and I know money is tight for many after what we’ve all been thru over the last couple of years 😷 but I’ve not exercised for sometime now and saw this challenge as a way to get fit again and thought if I can raise a little bit of money for a worthwhile cause along the way then all good. I’ve chosen this charity as my son was completely out the blue taken poorly back in 2016 and after urgent investigations was found to have a narrowing of the aorta and leaking heart valve. This was so shocking to us, he was 19 and up until then been a normal, fit, full of energy lad, he’d played football weekly since the age of 10 and we were completely oblivious to the health issues he had. This could’ve been a tragic story if we hadn’t found out and it only came to light purely by luck after the family obtaining a bp machine which everybody wanted to ‘have a go on’ When he done his the results were alarming to say the least. So much so I told him to “stop messing about and do it properly” Thank god we found out then. He’s since had a stent fitted and on meds but will need a heart op in the coming years. We are lucky,  this was discovered before something terrible happened, many others are not so lucky. So please donate what you can to this amazing charity ❤️ Thankyou xx

story:
Citi are aiming to raise 350,000 to enable Guide Dogs to create 178 life-changing partnerships. With our support, Guide Dogs will match people with sight loss on the London waiting list to guide dogs or volunteer sighted guides.

About Our London Charity Partner Guide Dogs

Losing your sight shouldn't also mean losing your independence, confidence and freedom, but unfortunately, our world is a tough place when you cant see. In the UK, there are 360,000 people who are blind or partially sighted and half of them do not leave their homes alone.

Guide Dogs provide life-changing services:
- Guide Dogs
- Volunteer sighted guides (My Guides)
- Support for children and young people
- Orientation and mobility specialists
- Technology
- Support for friends and family

story:
Former England international footballer Dave Thomas has set himself a new goal - to raise £100k for the charity Guide Dogs UK. Dave's sight has progressively deteriorated since he was diagnosed with glaucoma 20 years ago.  He was registered blind in 2008 and is the first ex-professional footballer to be registered blind and was awarded his guide dog Hannah four years ago.  Hannah has helped transform his life and maintain his independence.  After realising the huge difference Hannah made to him, Dave wanted to help others in similar situations and has been fundraising for the past few years.  

Players from Abbeydale Tennis Club are aiming to help Dave reach his target through a 24 hour Tennisathon starting at 8am on Saturday, 18 December.  Coaches Josh Gledden and Sam Salt will be partnered up for 24 hours with players throughout the day and night and your sponsorship and support will be much appreciated.

Almost two million people in the UK are living with sight loss that has a significant impact on their daily lives. Of those, around 180,000 rarely leave their homes alone and lead lonely, isolated lives. Guide Dogs works for a world where people with sight loss are never left out of life, for a world where being blind or partially sighted is not what defines you. A world with enough support to make the challenges of sight loss no barrier to fulfilling hopes and dreams.

Any support, sponsorship or donation you are able to give will make a huge difference.  Thank you.

story:
Hello everybody.....

As you can see I am taking part in the London Marathon in 2022 and here is my reason for doing this...

In 2010 a very special young child was born, Finley Twomey. Unfortunately it was not all plain sailing for him, Finley was born with a cleft lip and palate, however the cleft went all the way up to his skull which meant he had an opening in the front of his skull causing his brain to poke through, as a result of this his eye was also displaced.

When Finley was 2 months old he underwent major life threatening surgery to repair the hole in his forehead which involved the best surgeons in the world (who work at Great Ormond Street)

They managed to repair the hole using another part of his skull to keep his brain in place, the surgery lasted around 11 hours so it was a horrible time for everybody who loved him.

Since this surgery was completed he has also had surgery on his eyelid & lip as well as constant check ups at Great Ormond Street for various different reasons and to be honest it has just become a way of life for him.

Growing up Fin has always looked different to other kids but yet he is the happiest (when playing football) and most outgoing child you will meet, nothing seems to faze him whatsoever!

Early next year Finley has life changing surgery which will be performed by the worlds best surgeons at GOSH. They will be performing a procedure to move his eye up and get it symmetrical to the other side, this is absolutely huge for him!

Throughout all of this the GOSH team have been absolutely amazing with Fin and his family, every single staff member has been a credit to the hospital.

So why am I doing something?

Well I have been in Finleys life since the day he was born and love him like he is my brother. I have watched his whole journey unfold and been by his side all the way, I am super proud of the amazing child he is. I think it's absolutely incredible that there is a hospital that can help and change childrens life so I thought if I can give them something back then I will...

Me being me, I don't really do half measures so I thought I would go all out and run the London marathon, I have absolutely no idea how I'm going to do this, but I'll give it a good go!

To everybody reading this (including the haters) please give generously as I literally could not think of a better cause. 

Any support is appreciated.....

All hail king Finley

story:
Welcome to my Just Giving fundraising page! I am running the 2021 Supernova London for Cancer Research UK with my close friend Elizabeth Ulusele. Cancer Research UK is the world's leading charity dedicated to research on the causes, treatment and prevention of cancer. Thanks to research, more people are surviving cancer than ever before. Thanks in advance for any contribution to this cause that means so much to us. We have both been personally effected, losing family members to cancer and have decided to do this run in support of a charity that did so much to help our loved ones and our families.

William Ridley (30th October 1940- 7th October 2021)
William Ridley- my inspiration, my joy, my support- was not just a Grandad to me; he was my best friend. He fought hard for 8 years with lung cancer, despite the original bleak diagnosis of just a few months.  He taught me more about love and sacrifice then anyone I have ever known. My Grandad was my biggest supporter and all I have ever wanted is to make him proud. I know that he would have loved to be there with us on the 27th of November with a big smile (and a sausage sandwich.) I would like to take this opportunity to thank everyone that has helped me and my family during this difficult time - we truly do appreciate it. Please donate anything you can to try to this brilliant charity and cause. Thank you for all your kind messages but most of all; thank you Grandad. I miss you everyday and I hope I can make you proud.

story: This January I'll be taking part in Brave the Chill in aid of WWF. Sponsor me to help WWF protect our one shared home. Climate change poses the biggest threat to the future of our planet. The Earth's atmosphere is warming, faster than it probably ever has. This causes negative impacts such as the melting of Arctic sea-ice, prolonged heat-waves and rising sea-levels. It may seem a bit chilly for some of us, but the Arctic is crucial for lots of reasons. Its home to around four million people, including indigenous communities, and there's an amazing amount of wildlife too, all uniquely adapted to life in this icy landscape. Polar bears, penguins and walrus call this freezing landscape their home. But their environment is changing, because of global warming. The sea ice during the summer months is declining, and with global warming, that ice is shrinking fast. By sponsoring me to Brave the Chill, together we can help protect our one shared home.

I'm taking part in The Big Winter Wander, to reconnect with our country's beautiful wildlife and help protect it. The funds you help me raise will help WWF campaign to protect wildlife here, and around the world.

Nature has been there to offer us comfort during difficult times, and now its our time to give back.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

This year I created 31 ink drawings as part of INKTOBER2021. One drawing a day, every day of October – and no cheating – what kept me going was my plan to do this as a charity art sale for Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF). 

MSF does fantastic work providing vital medical care to people across the globe - in conflict zones, natural disasters and epidemics. 

Digital copy: £5
(this could buy dressing kits to clean war wounds)

Original artwork: £50 
(this could buy the personal protective equipment for a doctor treating ebola)

Digital copies of all 31 drawings: £100 
(this could provide a folding stretcher to help patients who have suffered emergency trauma)

You can find images of all 31 drawings and their corresponding numbers/titles in the gallery.


Art Sale - How does it work?

Digital copies:
If you wish to purchase a digital copy, just make your donation and send an email to cg.sketches@gmail.com telling me which drawing(s) you would like (number or title). I will send you a high quality PDF of the digitised drawing.

You can print your digital copy and put it up in your home, use it as a colouring page, get it printed on a t-shirt – what you do with it is up to you, as long as it’s for personal use only. If in doubt, just get in touch. 

Original artwork:
If you are buying original artwork, please email me at cg.sketches@gmail.com before making a donation to make sure that the drawing you are interested in is still available. All drawings are individual pieces - once they are gone, they are gone. If you are outside the UK, please let me know so we can figure out if shipping is feasible.

All original drawings are black ink on sketching paper (some original also feature gold or other inks), signed in pencil. Original size is ca 208 x 290 mm. You can find photographs of the original drawings on instagram @goebelchristina

This is very slightly smaller than A4, I can keep the sketch paper in it’s original state (retaining rough sketchbook edges) or trim to a smaller size (e.g. 8 x 10 Inches) for you depending on preference.

story:
The SSC will be celebrating the great work of one of our charity
partners, MSF, throughout November for MSF's 50th anniversary by
raising awareness and fundraising through the #MSF50for50 Challenge.

Médecins Sans Frontières/Doctors Without Borders (MSF) was officially created on 22nd December 1971. MSF are an international, medical humanitarian organisation working in more than 70 countries around the world.

The wonderful thing about 50 for 50 is that there are challenges you can seek sponsorship for, ones to do personally for you, and ones you can do to raise awareness about MSF. Activities can be done individually or as a team, and can take 50 days or just 50 seconds – it’s up to you!

Take on a challenge or organise an event:

We recommend setting yourself a minimum fundraising target of £50 and set up a JustGiving page, linked to this page.  Some ideas are set out below:

  • Set yourself a physical challenge – walking, running, cycling, skipping or swimming your way to 5km, 50km, 50 lengths,
    50,000 steps a week or more!
  • Showcase your skills by taking on a challenge to a multiple of 50
  • Bake 50 cupcakes or organise a bake sale and charge 50p a cake
  • How many books can you read in 50 days?
  • Movie Marathon – watch 50 Oscar winning movies
  • Team challenge – reach 50,000 burpees, mountain climbers or squats together
  • Can you play an instrument? Are you a talented cook? Maybe you’re a qualified yoga instructor. Ask for donations to share your
    expertise with your networks by hosting a 50 minute insight into your craft or activity
  • Take on a 50 Hour Challenge – a challenge alone or in a team and relay the time
  • Put £1 in a jar every time you forget to press 'unmute' over 50 days
  • Host a Team Quiz Night and ask everyone to pay £5 to take part
  • 50 Days of Kindness – you could choose to make tea for your colleagues, bake cakes, carry the shopping for someone… – anything that makes those around you happy.
  • Take part in P/hop - a fundraising knitting project, the proceeds of which go directly to MSF.
